A - Pours a very dark brown, with a small beige head.

S - Rustic caramel malt, burnt toffee, charred apples, earthy peat, deep sorghum molasses, cocoa, smoked malts, the caramel malt runs from front to back.

T - Charred caramel malt, rugged smoked tea-like bitterness, chocolate, molasses, plum fruit, burnt cereal grain, finishes smoky and bitter.

M - Incredibly smooth, full body, perfect amount of carbonation.

Dense malt profile, smokey, charred, bittersweet flavors meld with an almost perfect mouthfeel. Good drinker for a February evening.

Serving type: bottle

02-01-2013

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2013 Pours a deep copper amber color with a fat, soapy, tan head. Toffee and fruit nose you get off of a British brown. Moutfheel is very slick with some carbonation scrub coming midway. Seems the quintessential British brown ale. Smooth, easy drinking, and figgy/pruny. Not much flavor from the barrel fermentation.  Faint vanilla occasionally.

500ml Bottle. 7.2%. Dark brown/black pour with a bubbly tan foam with medium retention. Aroma is roasted malts, toffee. Taste is quite sweet at first, malt and toffee, full bodied. I enjoyed this beer more as it started to warm. Lingering sweetness with a hint of almonds, chocolate, espressoey bitterness. Simple, sweet, and delicious.
Had two sips and the glass fell off the back of the car at lake wedding ton.

Bottle @ home. profumo di malto tostato con interessante richiami alla nocciola , al caramello, ed al legno. Colore rosso rubino, anche se filtrata lascia apparire una leggera sedimentazione. Schiuma giallognola compattissima. Gusto ancora più deciso, rotondo, avvolgente e pastoso. Si avverte di più la tostatura e un piacevole luppolato fresco e morbido. Il gusto più intenso è quello del legno. ottima con cibi saporiti e salata per il suo gusto pieno e fresco contemporaneamente.
Dark ruby with small head. Aroma thin with dark fruits, malt, chocolate. Taste Malty with dark fruits and bittersweet chocolate. Medium palate, carb aver. Finish bittersweet.

Very dark pour thats almost opaque. Quite a bit of head that is leaving some very appealing lacing. The carbonation actually sticks to the side of the glass (you can really see it in the sadly fuzzy pic I got. Smells boozy. Malty, raisins and maybe a touch of cherry. 

Not nearly as boozy in the mouth. Caramel. Something just a touch smoked that hits in the back of the throat. Oh theres the boozyness, all in the finish. Its rich and warming. Theres something bitter in the aftertaste. Woody. Rather complex. 

Very good but a bit much. Glad I only have one. Not a session beer.

Best Before June 2018, 500mL bottle from BevMo near Liberty Station. No idea in hell how Ive not rated this like six years ago. Clear medium reddish brown with a 1 1/2 finger beige head, thick with pretty good retention. Malty aroma of toasted malt, some raisin, prune, and ripe sweet cherry notes, some minerals. Flavor added a bit of stale graham crackers (though not sweet) and a slight fruity tang. Not necessarily picking up on any oak, though according to the description it was only oaked for seven days of fermentation. No trace of alcohol noted, semi-dry, bitterness peaked at a twoish. Medium body with light prickly carbonation. Good, but not a beer I"ll seek out often. On cask, however, Id definitely give it another go (as unlikely as Id ever find it).
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a deep brown with a nice head. Smooth mouthfeel. Dark fruit flavor and a rich caramel aftertaste.

(33 cl bottle) Dark brown coloured, clear, with a small light beige head. Initial impression is an aroma of pure licorice pastilles, and a little metallic. After a while, some more roasted malty notes, dried fruit and sherry aromas come into the mix, and finally even a small trace of hops on the palate. Taste is rather sweet, with a moderate bitterness as well. Mouthfeel is less sticky than expected, medium to full body,  soft carbonation.  Might improve with keeping. Young as it is now, it is not among my favourites, mainly because I am not too fond of that licorice aroma. But thats just my taste - it is certainly a well-made and complex beer.
Poured from 33cl bottle. Dark brown with off-white head. Deep dark red fruit aroma with some caramel and roast. Same taste, but pretty thin texture.

Heck of a beer! Makes me proud to be Scottish. Pours a clear and looks like ice tea out of the bottle. Orange brown with a creamy, off-white head leaving quite fine lacework. Lovely aroma of sherry and overripe fruit. Full-bodied with a very soft and smooth mouth feel. Very complex flavor pattern with woody, mild oak accents and vanilla, caramel, sherry, plenty of fruit and even some vitamin accents and a nice smooth grain finish. The finish is dry. Very complex and pleasant Amazing.
DØE. Dark amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit and caramel. Flavour is malt, fruit, caramel, medium sweet, toasted, hop, little wood, little chocolate and a little bitter.

Pours brown, thick and hazy. Small head, off-white, creamy. Good lacing. Mild aroma, led by sweet chocolate, cookies, vanilla, smoothly fruity. Smooth palate, medium body, balanced finish. Taste is licorice, vanilla, amazing balance, deep and compex.
Intense brown colour, medium carbonation. Toffee, banana and mature fruit gorgeous aroma. Full bodied taste with some bitterness at the end as we expect from an irish ale.

33 cl bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika. Pours clear red with a very small beige head. Aroma of malts, raisins and caramel. Some weak notes of wood and alcohol.  Flavour is sweet and this is a dessert beer. Low carbonation, medium sweetness, slick mouthfeel. Well balanced.

Bottle. Quite a nice wee beer from Traquair house (the oldest inhabited house in Scotland!). Pours a ruby red body, little to no head, quite a peaty aroma. Liquorish and malty taste with a light spice and warming finish. Lovely!

Pours a clear dark red. Thin tan head that dissipates fairly quickly. Strong, sweet aroma of malt and dried fruit. Flavor is raisins, dried cherries, toast and just a hint of vanilla. A little more alcohol burn than usual for the style. Medium body. Slightly slick, oily finish and very mild carbonation.

Great colour  - deep ruby red, looks like ribena, unfortunately it has about as much head as a ribena too. Aroma is malty, cereal, some biscuit, port, alcohol. Flavour is mild sweetness, a bit of bitterness, well balanced, but definately missing something. The texture is slick, but very thin. Drinkable, but not great.

Bottle. Dark amber, average fully diminishing head. Moderate to full, malty and sweetish aroma, some caramel and roasted malt, light dark fruits, some notes of wood - light vanilla, light hoppyness. Body is medium to full, malty and sweetish flavor, some caramel and roasted malt, light dark fruits, some notes of wood, light hoppyness.  Finish is average to long, malty and lightly sweetish, some caramel and roasted malt, some notes of wood - light vanilla, light hoppyness and faint alcohol. Really nice strong scotch ale - not too sweet/too much caramel, not too oaky.

500 ml bottle.  Pours a dark amber color with very little head, no lacing.  Aroma is rich caramel malt, cocoa, and oak.  Taste is smooth and fairly complex.  Moderate sweetness is nicely balanced by a light peaty smoke and cocoa.  Light bitterness and a small burnt oak flavor.  What keeps this from being great is that its thin and a little watery.  Love the flavors here the mouthfeel is below average.

Bottle 0,33L. Black colour with fizzy brown head, that falls quickly in a nice circle. Very malty aroma of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, cherries and oak cask barrels. There is also some alcohol note, but its well hidden. Taste is moderate sweet at first, but turns into a moderate bitter aftertaste and long lasting finish feel. Full bodied, oily ale with almost no carbonation. Excellent beer, very close to perfect!
Dark red / brown with nice white head. Roasted aromas. Light and very smooth with taste of mocca and chocolate.

Clear, very dark red body with a small, very light-brown head. The head reduces quite quickly to a partially covering film, in addition to a ring of big bubbles that refuse to disappear, but are unable to leave much footprint on the glass. Strong, complex and sweet aroma with both well ripe and dried dark fruits. There are also some very pleasant and well integrated vinous port-like notes, a touch of vanilla in the back and also some faint spicy notes, I think I get anise. Moderate sweet and moderate bitter taste. The moderate but complex flavours follow the aroma, with the fruity components having a stronger emphasis on the dried and dark, like mild prune. I also get some obvious notes of caramel that I didnt initially pick up in the aroma. Finally spices and herbs in the back. Medium body, oily texture and a bit too soft carbonation. A pleasant one. 
[33 cl bottle, enjoyed 8 years before BB date, from Vinmonopolet Vika, Oslo]

the aromas are intoxicating... molasses, toffee- sweet malts and some alcohol... pours dark with good head and lacing. the taste is a little lighter than expected. theres some savoury characters that linger nicely on the palate, as well as the sweet malt notes. not hugely complex but a lovely ale.

Bottle from Selfridges, Birmingham. Thin in the mouth, yes; but rich still. Deep licorice finish, preceded by a dry, flinty malt. Feel proficient. Or prescient. Or both. Or neither. Not sure what prescient means.

Tap @ The Oak Barrel. Dark reddish brown colour, dissapearing head. Sweet wooden malty aroma with vanilla. Wooden sweetish oak barrel malty taste with touch of salted licorice. Medium+ body and nice balance.
Bottle from Slowbeer. Nice and malty. Aromas of caramel, toffee, wine, hint of liquorice. Taste is sweet, with bitter notes, long length. Palate is syrupy, and full bodied. Brown, with a thin head.

Poured from a bottle into a glass. Appearance is black with a white, near gray head that leaves some good lacing. Smells a bit chocolatey. Not much more aroma. Taste is a bit flat up front, but evolves into cocoa, some cola, a bit of oak/woodiness, and an abrupt mildly bitter finish. No flavors really stand out, everything is melded together.
Oil like look with a thin head.  Chocolate and warmth with a thin malt.  A very nice sipping ale.  Would like to try and aged one.
Smak och doft choklad, malt, karamell, läder, citrus och toner av brunt socker och vanilj. Lagom söt och besk.

Bottle. 4/11/13. Pours a lightly translucent dark brown with a thin quick fading off-white head. Aroma is caramel, vanilla, fruit, toffee, biscuits, wood, spicy. Taste is pretty dry; alcohol, leather, fruit, just a touch of smoke, some citrus tanginess, more bitter than the aroma would suggest; bitter finish, difficult to place. No lacing. Slightly chewy mouth feel. Medium-low carbonation. More dry and bitter than I was anticipating. Not bad, but not one I would come back for a second bottle of.

Pint bottle. Poured a clear deep brown color with a tiny head that vanished almost immediately. Roasted malt, dark fruit, and oak. Alcohol hidden well, a little too watery on the palate for me. Low-medium carbonation.
Pours cola brown with a minimal head. Aroma is over ripe apples and yeast - almost like cider. Taste is not fruity at all. Instead you get rich malts. Theres something comfortable about this one.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2015 March 2013 - 2011 bottle.  Light malty smell.  There is a lot of rum in the flavour, dates, old ale.  Quite sweet and a little sharp.  Despite all the sweetness, there is a bit of savoury too.  Distinctive British old ale qualities, probably the best of the type Ive had so far.  Quite tasty. (3.6)
June 2015 - 2011 bottle share.  Thanks to Paul and Jack for these.  Aroma is meaty, sherry.  Taste is bready, spice, soft bitterness.  (3.6)
June 2015 - 1991 bottle share.  Aroma is cola, sherry, mint.  Taste is thin, flat cola, earth, sweet.  (3.7)
June 2015 - 1985 bottle #45.  Aroma is oxidised, sweet plum and red wine, light vegetal notes.  Taste is oxidised, meaty, bovril, some chocolate, light bitterness.  Interesting. (3.5)
June 2015 - 1977 bottle share.  Aroma is apple, some banana ester, booze, vegetable stock cubes.  Taste has apple, bread, some booze.   (3.4)

Nose is strong nut with a hint of brown sugar. Appearance is a cola with a small head leading to lacing. Taste is smoke leading to nut with a sharp bitterness. Mouthfeel was a little thin.

Overall, I found it too bitter compared to other Scotchs I have sampled, and lacking the same depth of flavor. Enjoyable however.

Bottle shared at beers of the world.  Aroma is slight hardwoods, malty goodness and a molasses sugar.  Pours transparent brown with a nice bubbly film.  Taste is light and malty with great brown ale roast notes and some earthy wood.  Lighter than your average scotch ale but very easy to kick back.  I liked this one.

Une Ale très sombre avec mousse somptueuse. Epaisse, persistante et onctueuse, elle est a elle seule un regal. Des aromes pussants et envoutant de biscuits, café, caramel, avec des notes de grillé. Plonger son nez dans son verre deviens addictif. Malheureusement, une fois en bouche elle ne develope plus grand chose et son manque de puissance et de corps déçoivent comparativement aux aromes.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2015 Limpido color caramello con un sottile velo di schiuma biancastra. Al naso sentori dolciastri di biscotto, caramello, legno e zucchero di canna; gusto asciutto anchesso dolciastro con note di toffee, frutta sciroppata ed un tocco legnoso nel finale. Corpo medio, effervescenza debole, buona persistenza ma non particolarmente gradevole per i miei gusti.

Reviewed 2/9/13.16.9 oz bottle into a nonic pint glass.

A: Pours a deep cola brown color. The head is a one finger white shade which quickly descends into a thin film. Lacing is okay.

S: This is quite caramel-forward in its malt profile, and also some biscuity malt/yeast interplay as well. Theres an element of dry chocolate here, alongside some brown sugar, molasses I have some trouble detecting the oak barrel here, but its not a negligible presence. Quite pleasant.

T: At first, I notice some vaguely smoky caramel malts, before giving way to some brown sugar and molasses. The exhales present a lot of smoky chocolate on the palate - and is probably my least favorite aspect of this, due to how dangerously close they come to tasting like flatulence. Unlike Jacobite, theres a faint presence of leafy, herbal finishing hops which helps balance the sweet maltiness in conjunction with the barrel tannins. Not particularly complex, but it goes down with superb ease.

M: Extremely clean and dry finishing. A slight amount of alcohol-concealing residual sugar lingers past the initial tannin presence - however after a while the tannic quality accumulates, which goes even further toward drying the palate out. I might even surmise that the heavy (but not harsh) dryness kills its potential complexity. Firm yet gentle carbonation helps ease this one down superbly.

O: Personally, Im more inclined to prefer a less bone-dry Scotch ale (like Old Chub). Im also a bit let down in its lack of depth; but on the flipside, the drinkability this presents is impressive. All things considered, a bit too expensive ($8/16.9 oz) given that it seemingly focuses on drinkability over complexity. That doesnt mean it isnt very good, however.
Bottle 0.33l at Bar Molotov, Helsinki. Colour is dark brown with small brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Spices, dark fruits and roasted malts.

Pours a clear dark amber/garnet with a full antique lace head.  Good retention and lacing.  Earthy brown bread aroma.  Smooth and delicious.  Sweet roasted malt with an ever so slight bitter hop bite.  Buttery roasted nuts also noted in the taste.  This is a great traditional Scottish ale, nothing pretentious but very good at it.

33cl bottle from Vinmonopolet, Vika. Pours clear dark brown with a pale beige head. Aroma of raisins, malt and caramel with hints of alcohol, wood and roastiness. Sweet and slightly reminiscent of fortified wine. Quite desserty, but well balanced. Nice beer for the colder months.
Bottle. Very complex dark sugar and fruit aromas. The changing flavors remind me more of a Belgian quad. Sweetened up a bit as it warmed.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark red brownish color. No head. Aroma of caramel and rich malts. Flavor is quite sweet, rich caramel flavors and some coffee touches. Full bodied and thick mouthfeel. Quite nice.

33 cl bottle.
Originally rated on 20090721.
Pours dark brown color with a small head. Aroma of caramel, malts and mild fruits. Flavor of caramel malts, sugar, yeast, earth and some toffee. Decent.
Traquair. Exodus. Richie had a brilliant collection of Buxton. Looks awesome. Love that brewery. Gonna be by the Bs. Did someone say "B"?
Wife said fortified. Everyone else says raisins. I can sense the top fermented wort. Definitely the mark of seven days. Bit thin for me but a tasty Monday night treat.

Pours a slightly hazy chestnut with. Very thin head, but plenty of lacing around the edges. Aroma is toffee, vanilla, some nice subtle oaky notes. Taste is pleasant bitterness which is off set by a sweet malty backbone some alchohol burn.

33 cl bottle @ Oak Barrel, Helsinki‐Vantaa airport. Rated on 13.07.2009
Aroma is somewhat spicy with ripe fruits and toffee. Flavour has roasted notes, some vanilla, ripe fruits, toffee and spices. Like a light version of Jacobite Ale.
Rich aroma of sweet toffeeish malt with raisin and perhaps a touch of vanilla.    Flavor adds a mild sweet coffee note and a nice hint of bitterness

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2013 Dark brown, mahogany body with small grey head. Bock like aromas worth spices like cinnamon and nutmeg, raisins, dark malts, caramel and maple syrup. Light prickly carbonation that help lift the spicy bitterness and herbal sweetness. Full flavoured but not too alcoholic. Dryer notes towards the ending. Good taste, bit disappointing overall. (33cl bottle from Bière Révolution)

Bottle at home. Pours a pretty clear deep brown colour with a light beige medium head. Malty and sweet aroma of dried fruit, oak, leather and nuts. Wonderful, and like a proper brown ale. Lighter flavour than expected but still lots of malt along with rye bread, nuts and a touch of roasted coffee beans in the end. Light and slick mouthfeel, and a surprisingly medium bitterness. Lovely aroma and one of a kind taste. Pleasant.
Fruit, bread, toffee, and alcohol in the aroma.  Flavor starts sweet, with raisins, toffee, and bread.  A little bitterness and some alcohol in the finish.  Really good.
Superb. Malty. Do not serve too cold; the best swallow was the last when it had warmed up a bit. A great ale to enjoy after a hard day of fighting Englishmen.
Oak background is detectable in the aroma. Taste has some sweet flavours of dried fruits and sugars. Carbonation is low. Finish is very dry. Quite a rich beer.

Bottle shared.  Pours clear brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of overripe fruit, light caramel, malt, bread and raisins.  Flavour is over moderate sweet and light moderate bitter.  Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

35cl bottle courtesy of and shared with Kermis.  
Ok off white head.  Caramel taste.  Clear deep burgundy pour.  Nice brew.
Dark mahogany with creamy off-white head. Molasses and raisins are the most prominent aromas. Sweet malt, burnt toffee with hints of licorice round out the flavor profile. Excellent Scotch ale.

A half finger of light tan head on a brown/reddish colored body.
The aroma is caramel malt and oak. Its deeper than just those two scents. 
The texture is crisp, which balances the wood and caramel malt flavors. A moderate bitterness also plays against the malt to produce a balanced and nicely complex ale. Lower carbonation and medium body. 
An enjoyable ale with better than normal complexity and depth.
Bottle. Pours a red/brown with a small head. Sweet malt and alcohol nose. Flvaour is nutty, toffee and chocolate with some spice. Quite a boozy finish.

Pours cola-ruby-brown with a thick oatmeal head.
Aroma of roasty caramel, chocolate malt.
Taste is a silky smooth chocolate, caramel malt, bread.
Very smooth and easy.
Wonderful.

Half liter bottle (compliments of Santa aka jordanhumbert) - pours clear dark amber with ivory head and decent lacing. Nose is brown sugar, dark fruit, roasted malts and caramel. Flavor adds floral/herbal hops. Maltiness makes an appearance once the beer warms. Well balanced with medium sweetness and bitterness. Sticky mouthfeel. Alcohol aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013  One very good beer, one of my first english ale ever drink (Jacobite ale), dark colour with tan head, charachteristic aroma, bitter and dry taste, with good coffee and dark chocolate notes in the long final, very soft carbonation. I like this beer style!

On 35 cl bottle from Vnmonopolet Vika.
Dark color, good foam.
Aromas of malt, dried fruit, raisins
Medium body & medium/ high complexity.
Some sweetness- well balanced
Very enjoyable
REstrained but rich, deep brown, and earthy with hints of wood caramel woven in together into a seemless whole. Neither extreme or wimpy this has perfect balance and jusy caresses the mouth.

Pours brownish black with little head and some lacing.  Nice malty aromas, chocolate, nuts, and the smell of baking bread.  Bready notes in the mouth too, together with licorice, chocolate and a very faint smokiness.  Little evidence of hops, but nicely balanced.  Very enjoyable, actually went back and gave this a higher overall because it went down sooooo easy.

Pours a clear brown color with an off white head that leaves lots of lace. Smell is of toffee and lots of Munich malts. Taste is a big on Munich malts and toffee with a nice smooth bitterness on the finish.

A really dark coffee colour with one finger head which leaves a bit of lacing. Aroma is toffee, chocolate, dark fruits, and hints of coffee and alcohol. Taste is much the same as the nose. Full bodied and creamy mouthfeel. I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle. Brown, dark mahogany. Nose has sweet malts, raisins, plums. At this point Im wondering whether this will be another undrinkable alcohol syrup. Some oak also. Body is medium. A bit yeasty. Dry even, and q bit bitter. Doesnt feel syrupy or repulsive. Rather well balanced. Brown malts, raisin, a bit of port and yeast. Quite nicely balanced strong ale.-- bb/h
Copper pour, cream colored head. Really nice looking beer. Nose is orange coriander, Christmas spices, citrus fruits, earth. Taste is spices, orange, orange coriander, graham cracker, nuts.

33cl bottle at El Pedal. Back colour with minimal beige head, short lasting. Aroma is light malty, toasty and slightly chocolate. Flavor has toasted malts notes with a mild alcoholic sensation. Caramel traces are present in the aftertaste. Carbonation and body are medium.
Bottle. Good taste. Good  strong and malty. Dark amber, brown color. Not much head.
A very earthy beer. A bit spicy. Nutty malts almost woody as if from a cask. Although I simply picked it up at BevMo. Poured transparent brown. Recommended. She is different.

Shared bottle at Cardinal. Clear deep ruby body with an off white film leaving good lacing. Fruity nose and some dried fruits. Sweet, fruity and toasted caramel on the nose. Full bodied. Smooth to drink. Dry tongue.

Fra flaske på Cardinaltreff: lakris og vanilje (gjæret på eikefat!), mykt, velbalansert  og innsmigrende med stor munnfylde. Et fantastisk øl helt uten skarpe kanter. Lurer på hvordan en ufiltrert utgave ville smakt...
Dark copper in colour, head disapearing quickly. Aroma of prunes, maple syrup and dark caramel. Wonderful taste. Aftertaste of dried fruit, toffee, dark caramel balanced with hop bitterness.
Sample on tap at Bières et saveurs (Chambly). Aroma and flavour: mostly malt and caramel Taste is sweet. A bit heavy.

Bottle (330 ml). Dark copper with a medium diminishing beige and and nice lacing. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, bread, wood, dark fruits. Taste is sweet, malt/caramel, bread, roasted malt, salty, dark fruit, peated notes and slight bitter finish. Mouthfeel is oily and leaves the mouth dry. Theres some of brandys characteristics (and aftertaste) in this beer. Interesting.

Botella de 330ml. Copa Globo. Saboreada en agt´12. Color marrón oscuro y espuma beige claro sin demasiada retención. En nariz, fragancias de levadura, florales y herbales, aromas de maltas caramelo y tostadas con trazos de anís. Gentil calidez alcohólica al primer sorbo redondeada por un sabor tostado. Cuerpo medio y carbonatación media-alta. Frutos oscuros en el intermedio con leve toque de chocolate y sutiles notas de anís. Final seco y malteado con retrogusto dulce y cálido.
330ml bottle. Snifter glass. Enjoyed on agt´12. Dark brown in color. Light beige head shows not much retention. Yeast, floral & herbal fragrances, caramel & toasted malt aromas & hints of anise to the nose. Gentle warming alcohol at firs sip rounded by toasted flavor. Medium body. Moderate to high carbonation. Oily to watery texture. Dark fruits in the middle, slightly chocolate touch & subtle anise notes. Dry malty finish. Sweet & alcoholic aftertaste.

Taste is very malty, but not as sweet as a lot of Scottish ales. Woody flavors, oaky, tastes like it was probably barrel aged. Traces of molasses, some smoke, ashy, a touch of scotch and the barest hint of buttered toffee. Finishes dry with a very faint mild alcohol burn in the afters.
Dark brown body, thin now you see it now you dont foam.  Some earthiness, sweet malt alcohol and medium bitterness.  Even the Scots can brew a decent English Strong Ale.
330 ml bottle. Pours brown with medium head that dissipates quickly but with nice lacing. Aroma of figs and roasted malts. Smooth. Flavors of sugary malts and fruitbread with light bitter finish.
330ml bottle - a deep ruby with a thin white top, a rich aroma of cake fruits, cherries and raisins. A nice oily feel to this, malty in taste with a boozy kick afterwards, nice lingering bitterness.

330ml bottle. Pours a deep semi-opaque brown with a moderate off white head. Aroma is very dark malt, fruits, caramel and molasses. Taste reminds me of whiskey, some molasses. Trace of earthy bitterness in the back. Booze is well masked. Body is quite thick, but is very smooth. Alcohol is well masked. Overall, an excellent English strong.

It draws you in and makes you feel like burrowing in amongst the wonders of a woodland. A beer of its place - bier de terroire.  Earthy bog swamp and blackberry aromas, breaking into a treacley burnt sugar aspects with complicated mushroom and liquorice vanilla complexity.  Very thought provoking. Is this an ale or a stout? How do they make this taste this way?
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 Dark ruby colour with nice head. Aroma is malt, sweet. Flavour is sweetish, nutty, caramel, dark fruits, long lasting taste. Maybe 3 year old bottle was even better.

Bottle. Nice aroma. Nice on the palate. Solid scotch ale. Served at about 55. Enjoyable alcohol finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Beer Street BK. Deep brown and ruby edged with diminishing head into a nice ring and surface lacing. The aroma is less subtle and perfum-y than the jacobite.  Dark fruit, caramel, bread and vanilla, dusty grassy hops, cedar, spices, nuts.  The flavor is more has a bit of spice and a hint of licorice on a caramel malt backbone with nuts and dark fortified vinous flavor wrapping through it.  The feel is soft and velvety though thin and the wood rises and lingers alongside respectable spice and bitterness.  A great beer that is well balanced though somewhat more direct and less rounded than the Jacobite.

Tasting @ Bestway. Thin brown pour. Little to no head. Light nutty nose. Spicy, peppery, oak-like notes. Weak, watery body. Imbibed for the experience. Not a favorite. The history of the brewery is more interesting than the beer.

Bottle from Selfridges. Colour is lovely rusty brown clear red, thin off white froth head. Nose is fruit estery, with banana, dark fruit, dried dates. Theres bread yeast, peat, fruit bread, touch of barrel wood. Taste is dark fruit, malty ale, dry barrel woody, banana ester, dried dates and prunes, and theres some bitter tang. Bitter tang, aged wood and dark fruit on the finish. Interesting beer which is full of flavours. Kind of thing that would be nice to drink in front of a log fire.
Bottled and chilled. A fine dark ruby color, with an off white head.  Nose is fruity. Flavor is malty and fruity, redolent of vanilla, caramel and raisins. Nice.

Murky brown color with a thin white ring. Oak barrel is dominant on the nose. The palate is a great mix of figs, caramel and roasted nuts. For such a brooding beer, this is surprisingly lively on the palate.

Bottle. A clear dark amber/brown beer, with an average sized. frothy, lacing, fully lasting off-white head. The aroma is moderately malty (toasted/roasted nuts, chocolate, caramel), with notes of banana, toffee, sherry. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Medium body, watery/velvety texture, soft/lively carbonation, not very long or intense finish with moderate bitterness, lightly alcoholic. Very interesting aroma, even though a bit oxidized, nutty and fruity. Rather watery and thin mouth experience.

Bottle @ home. Pours a deep reddish brown appearance with a light brown head. A bit smoky, rich toffee, caramel malty, light chocolate, a bit fruity aroma. Big burnt sugar, toffee, dark caramel malty, light chocolate, somewhat smoky, herbal flavor. Pretty interesting.
Wässriger, etwas oxidierter Beginn mit dezenten Malznoten. Süffig, insgesamt leider etwas langweilig. Besonders zum Ende deutlich wässrig, geringe Malzigkeit. 8/8/9/8/8/8
Bottle - not much head, very dark amber color, very sweet malty aroma and flavor, with some alcohol taste

330ml bottle. Brown beer that just about forms a beige cap. Very interesting aroma with initial chocolate notes followed by treacle, toasted nuts and caramel. Upon first sip this almost tastes like an old fashioned medicine but once adjusted this ale becomes much tastier, with a lovely sweet liquorice finish and a subtle spiciness. The mouthfeel is thinner than I expected but sits well with the traditional character of this beer. To drink it feels like stepping back in time.

Pours a medium brown, very minimal head, but moderate carbonation. Taste is malt forward, almost sweet, with carmel notes, slightly complex. HInts of roasted grain come through. Pretty balanced, but leaning slightly malt forward. Finishes with just bit of bitterness on the back of the tongue. No alcohol comes through. A nice ale.
Dark fruit aromas. Smooth ale with medium carbonation. Finishes sweet. Decent.
33cl, Scottish brew, from Beers of Europe Setchey, complex brew, malty/sweet and slightly woody/spicy, easy to drink, very balanced, clear, small head, good brew

Bottle. Very dark orange brown pour with a foamy white head. Earthy malt notes. Peaty bitters but a soft fizzy finish. Some notes of leather and hay. Asphalt. Gently sweet. Body reads a bit watery. Nice, but not as full, complicated and interesting as their Jacobite offering.

Pours a slightly muddy brown with a hint of white foam that disappears very quickly.  Subtle aromas of sweet malts, earthy oak and a hint of alcohol.  On the palate it follows the nose well... round full mouthfeel, little carbonation, and rich flavors of earthy moss, oak and a touch of caramel... there is a underlying bitterness that really goes a long way to make this more enjoyable than I though it would be based on smell alone.

Dark red-amber with decent, creamy, tan head / Mellow but rich, sweet nose of cream, oak, caramel, and chocolate / Medium body, a touch watery, soft carbonation, malty and sweet, with good balance and fair finish / Somewhat simple flavors of nuts, toast, caramel, oak, and cinnamon  / Body surprisingly weak.

Dark brown, almost black colour. Minimal white head that fades away quickly. Great aroma, spice and malt. Nice mouthfeel, soft with very little carbonation. Very refreshing taste with slight bitterness in the end. Very nice beer.

Poured from a refrigerated bottle into a brandy snifter. Appearance is a dark ruby hue with a light khaki colored head of foam that  dissipates to just more than a coating atop the beer. Aroma is roasty, cacao beans, something like a hot chocolate powder mix with a bit of bacon thrown in to give a smoked feel. Tastes super roasty and semi-sweet. Not much in the way of hop influence until the very end, where a drying occurs on the sides of the tongue. Umami describes the taste of this beer fairly well - savory - and on the verge of being salty. Theres a lot going on with this beer. Im glad I finally picked a bottle of this up.
330ml bottle from Appellation Wines, Edinburgh - clear dark brown ale, thin white head, roasted malt aroma, flavour is caramel malt, hint of vanilla, spicy, not as sweet as I would have liked

Bottle @ Oak Barrel, Helsinki-Vantaa Airport

Pours dark brown, almost black with a nice smooth head. Aroma of ripe fruits, plum, malts, spices. Taste is roasty and malty with some ripe fruits and spices. Finish is slightly roasty and spicy. Nice, quite well balanced and complex ale.

Bottle.  Nice dark color. When pouring glass I caught a hint of chocolate in the aroma.  Has a thin light brown head that quickly disappears.  Has a smooth mouth feel and not at all heavy.  Taste is quite good.  I would definitely recommend this ale.

11.2 oz bottle. My first-ever ale from Traquair, poured into a snifter. Minimal sort of khaki head. Khaki web of head floating on the surface. Small bubbles on the side of the glass. Hazy dark red-brown color. Little lace. Nice, light crisp carbonation, drier texture. Nice, dark fruity malty estery aroma, very interesting. Kind of like molasses, but not sticky or heavy, kind of somehow fresh tasting, actually. Light hops. Nice sweet taste, light bitter. Pretty interesting and tasty ale.

Bottle from Ølkonsortiet, Ålborg. Pours clear dark amber with a tiny tanned head. Aroma of caramel, bread and red ripe fruits. Taste is almost the same, sweet bready malts, red ripe fruits. Medium bodied.

April 2011: Brought this beer home from Las Vegas last year, strange to bring a Scottish beer back to the UK, but we dont see Traquair House beers around here!

330ml bottle poured into a Hoegaarden Grand Cru stemmed tulip.

Lovely dark brown/reddy colour, tan coloured tightly knitted foamy head. The head left some good lacing on the glass, so condition of the beer was good.

Dark chocolate smells come from the beer, coffee esters also in the mix for my nose.

The flavours followed the smells, chocolate and coffee, with the coffee being the dominant one this time. The alcohol content is just below the surface, but can just about he found as the mouth dries after each sip. Not as sweet as I thought it might be, or expected after the first sniff. This ia a well balanced brew for a Wee Heavy.

Dark brown with thin white lacy head. Smell of malt licorish and an aweful skuny sulfur smell. Smells old and stale. Woody Medium oily body. Taste like rot, and wood, with malt and bad fruit. Syrup and sweet. Aweful. Strong alcohol.taste. I cant say there are many nice things to say about it. Maybe if it was aged for 10 years we would hqve somthing to talk about.
Bottle. Pours a clear ruby/brown with almost no foam. Smells sweet with hints of currents and prunes. Tastes sweet with hints of brown sugar and prunes. Feels thin and light without much flavor.

33 cL bottle from Beers of Europe into a Westmalle glass.  Dark red brown with a short-lived creamy head.  Nicely hopped aroma, rich and a little chocolatey, a hint of trappist.  Rich, dry and fruity, a hint of roast and nut.  Reasonably good but not distinctive enough.

Pours dark brownish burgundy with a small white head that recedes quickly to a mere ring of bubbles around the edge of the glass.  Nose is ginger, butterscotch, rich caramel, dark fruits, banana and sweet pastries.  Flavor is sweet up front, then bitter joins in the middle to take over in the end with a great bitter finish.  Medium body, fizzy and crisp, long aftertaste.  Great beer.

Friday night brew from ideal cheese shop across the street.  Pours root beer brown with one finger beige head.  Nose of toffee and cocoa.  Tastes of caramel, rum, brown sugar, malt, and coffee.  Slightly sweet and not bitter at all.
Hazy, brown/amber pour. Slight caramel front with strong tone that finishes with distinct Scottish maltiness.

On a boat, pub. Bottled. Pours dark red with a thin head. Aroma is sweet roasted malt with a gentle hopping. Leather. Alcohol is not bothering. Taste: Slightly sweet, and some coffee bitterness. Palate: Quite light bodied. A bit thin texture, almost watery. Dry hoppy finish. 24.3.2012.

Pours a ddep brown almost mahogany color with aroma of sweet plums.  Taste is clean with a mild alcohol flavor throughout.  A sweet roasty taste with a mild bitter aftertaste.  A good strong ale that I would drink again.
Dark and tasty, hints of a dark coffee. Perfect mix of a heavy beer that is easy drinking.

First introduced to this classic Scottish barley wine at the 1983 Edinburgh Beer Festival. Dispensed by gravity from a small wooden barrel, it seemed to wriggle thickly from the spout!! Black ruby in colour with a thin creamy off white head. Strong, powerful and a distinctive sherry like/christmas pudding aroma, long in intensity. Very, very thick mouthfeel, with a luxurious silky smooth single cream texture. Potent flavours vie for attention from the dark malt complexes. Moist maltloaf laced with molasses and booming syrupy dates, prunes, plums, raisins  and treacle toffee. There is a slight nod to the hops with a brief prickle in the aftertaste. Finish is pure Scottish malt and it comes in a tidal wave of oak cask sherry warmth with a hint of vanilla and dark American chocolate. This is a traditional Scottish Barley Wine and a rare bird to find in cask even up here. Highly recommended.
Color Marron rojizo con una gran espuma beige poco duradera. Aroma a caramelo, cereal y frutos secos. Cuerpo medio con sabor Toffe y muy maltosa.
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2012 Tostatura leggera leggera. Si sente un pò di prugna e di caramello. Lalcol è presente eccome. Risulta essere anche un pò vinosa. Bevetela!

brown, bright, cream-colored head, thin, but with good retention.  Aroma is a light, grainy sweet caramel.  hint of bread.  fresh, neutral.  Light-medium bodied, silky, creamy carbonation.  Flavor is a clean scottish sweet with only a hint of bitterness, then some melonoidin that make you crave more on your palate.  A little toffee in the flavor that isnt in the aroma.  Despite the light body, a good sipper that only improves as it warms.  Drank it over an hour.

A malty, caramel aroma. Pours quite thin with a deep brown colour. Taste is a fairly basic malt body, with a fairly quick drop off leaving a insipid, washy bitterness.  As the beer warms there is another sour bread flavour which is tantalising but seems to dissipate rapidly and doesnt last long in the mouth. It is really a surprisingly dry for what has the appearance of a hearty malt. As a result, I suspect that it would do better as an accompaniment to food.

Pours a murky brown, with a smallish beige head that fades fairly quickly. Not really a looker, and it actually doesnt appear filtered like they say. Nose is delicious -- like sweet malted candy. Brown sugar, rum, caramel-drenched fruit, and a hint of oak. Flavor isnt nearly so robust, but is still nice. Bittering hops come through, and that lovely malty depth nearly completely disappears. Some fruit and sugar is left over, but the warmth is lost. Too bad!
Bottle; hazy brown with small beige head; aroma-cooked vegetable, roasty, molasses; moderate sweetness, mild bitterness and carbonation. Interesting and simple

12 ounce bottle. I find this to be am amazing beer each time I visit it. The grainy malts as well a the fruity character is always pleasing. I have not had many Scottish ales but this is what I would compare others to.
bottle at taberna belga, braga, portugal. Dark brown color. Thin head. Medium to high carbonation. Low to medium sweetness and low bitterness. Malt, caramel, light alcohol aroma.

12oz bottle in pint glass.  Pours medium dark like an opaque brown ale.  Aroma is indistinct to my nose but inviting, a bit of breadiness.  Taste is pretty good, not much on the front end, mild maltiness, a bit of bitterness and dryness.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden for 7%.   It took most of the 12oz bottle for me to really start noticing the sweetness.  I prefer the Jacobite but this is interesting.

It poured a dark brown color with a thick head. The aroma was of vanilla, wood, caramel, chocolate, raisin, and a some licorice. The taste was somewhat sweet with a little bitterness and a dry finish.  Overall, a good English Strong Ale.

Borrle into Chimay glass...

Aroma: Faint liquorice breadyness, fruitcake, toasty malts, alcohol, dried apricots and a sour funky note. Not a very aromatic beer but theres lots going on. 
Appearance: Transparent red color with minimal head on pour. BOOOOO
Taste: Its quite watery and lacks depth. Slight cough syrup, roasted malts and a yeasty finish. 
Palate: Disjointed and boring. A little light in body for a darker beer I think and theres no carbonation. Flavours seem transparent and passive minus the funky yeast finish. 
Overall: Disappointed, the Jacobite is better. This isnt horrible by any means...but not my style.

The beer pours a translucent, deep ruby color with a fairly small, frothy, beige head which is mostly diminishing and leaves minimal lace.  The nose is pleasant and very malt forward; lots of toffee and raisin, some brown sugar, almonds, and faint roast.  The flavor is less malt rich than I would have thought; raisin, almonds, dry oak, light roast, light brown sugar, and some faint leather.  The palate is silky but drying, more than medium, and less than lively.  The beer finishes drying, oaky, some leather, and faint raisin still.  An interesting beer with an incredibly drinkable nature and smooth palate.  The bitterness was fairly low but the beer never became cloying.  Very nice beer to drink but not incredibly memorable.

The aroma is a subtle blend of roast and caramel malts. The appearance is a deep brown with a tan head that fades into lots of lacing. The taste is a delicious bready malt with toast balances by a slight hop bitterness. The body is medium smooth and elegant. Suprisingly refreshing for such a strong dark beer. Great.

From tasting notes (2007): Good dark mahogany, russet colour under a whitish head. Aromas of intense malt, a little herbal in character with woodiness there as well. Tastes full, rich and unctuous. Not overly sweet, but mature. Additional flavours include raisins and dates. God this is good.

Pours a dark translucent amber with a beige head that quickly disappears. woodsy and malt aroma.  Goes down smooth. Taste is of malt and I detect something else but everytime I think I will get the full taste the bitterness takes over.  I really like this, but could have done with less bitterness.
Nice rich and smooth beer that has hints of roast and a good mouthfeel. I will re-rate if i ever get the chance to have on cask.

Translucent mahogany with a dense beige head. Creamy medium-full body with medium carbonation.

Aroma: roasty malt, metallic minerality, woodsy hops, and a touch of chocolate malt acidity.

Taste: rich chocolate malt, woodsy hops, roasty malt, mild minerality, a slight sourness, and subtle charred malt astringency.
Dark brown pour.  Malty nose with dark fruit.  Taste has more of a dark lager thing going on.  No need for another.
Bottle. Dark brown with tan head. Nutty aroma. Chocolate and nutty taste, toffe. Pretty good
Dark brown beer with almost no head at all. Aroma is malty with dark fruits and raisins. Flavour is dark fruits and raisins. Very nice.
moderate-dark brown color, medium body, complex taste and aromas - nutty, caramel,smoky and rich fruit flavors

330ml Bottle from Waitrose:
Dark malts hit the nose straight away and are quite rich. The malts seem to be infused with some dark fruit & caramel and I can also detect a little grain and some of the alcohol as well. There is a background sweetness coming from some vanilla and butterscotch along with a bit of spice as well.

Dark reddish brown with a large, two fingers sized off-white head that is quite foamy looking. Retention isnt too bad either with the head eventually settling to a thick looking lacing after about a minute or so.

Dark malts with some dark fruits upfront, perhaps some figs in the taste. There is some caramel and vanilla too and a sweet, warm finish and a malty aftertaste.

Medium bodied, with light carbonation and an oily texture to the drink. It leaves a lingering warmth from the alcohol as the aftertaste.

A great beer and probably the best of the style I have ever tried, it was a lot better than I had been expecting. An excellent beer to sit and sip away at and most likely one Ill pick up again.

Featured in the 1001 Beers To Try List:
/1001beers

Fruity aroma with a hint of oak and caramel. Pours from the bottle a deep ruby with a tiny cream head. Thin body with light carbonation. Toast, yeast, and hints of sweet malt overwhelm the palate. Oak is apparent in all phases of flight. Finish is sweet with continued fruit and mild alcohol. Well balanced.
33cl flaska. Mörkt kastanjefärgad öl med beige skum. Doft av jäst, kryddor och lite läder. En torr munkänsla. Ganska tillbakahållen i smakerna som går igen från doften.

33cl bottle. Pours toffee to chestnut in colour with a nice small head. The nose has ginger biscuits and cream. The taste has more creamy ginger biscuits. The palate is medium bodied and textured with a pleasant clean finish. Overall, this is very pleasant though a bit one-dimensional.

Bottle. (On vacation to WV about a month ago.) Fairly dark brown with light brown head. Smells banana bready and boozy. Tastes sweet but not cloying finishing with a dry roastiness (but not bitter). Light and well-blended.

Bottle @ Schouskjelleren, Oslo, shared with some guys from RBNAG 11. Dark red-hued clear brown body, small off-white head. Licorice, toffee, dark malts and caramel in the nose. Taste is smooth licorice and caramel tones interacting elegantly, with dark maltiness and hints of milk chocolate. A classic old ale from a classic Scottish brewery that Ive only now been acquainted with but will surely be looking out for in the future.

14.10.2011. 0,33 l Bottle. At Schoukjelleren, Oslo. Dark brown colour with off-white head. Aroma is malty. Good flavours of sweet malt. There are also raisins and notes of dry chocolate and coffee. Good beer!

0.33l bottle @ Schoukjelleren, Oslo. This one pours a deep deep red - almost brown - body with a fading bubbly beige and sidesticking head. The aroma has sweet licorice tones, some leather, dark malts and dried dark fruits. Soft to average carbonation with a oily mouthfeel. The flavors are dark malty, nice touch of licorice with a fruity and almost herbal finish. Quite alright.

Bottle at Mason and Taylor. Red brown coloured and quite see through. Aroma is very confusing. Earthy/mossy and malty. Bit oak boozy barrel too. Taste is very nice. Very smooth, even velvetty. Bit herby. Medium bodied. Cracking beer.

11.09.02 sampled at bieres et saveurs A: brown sugar, chocolate, caramel, dry raisins. App: clear brown beige head lasting. T/P : full body finish is sweet and medium long. O: Great sipper love the maltiness on that one.

Bottle. Pours a dark, chestnut brown with a negligible, beige head.  Aroma is malty, dried fruits, some dark fruits, raisin. Taste is dark malts, raisin, prune, tones of liquorice, a bit vinous, port or red, slightly medicinal flavor. Palate is full and smooth, no carbonation. Good, but loses to its big brother, Jacobite.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2011 Bottle from Waitrose, Byres Road, Glasgow.
Appearance - Chestnut brown, thin white head, moderate lacing, clear.
Aroma - Complex aroma of dark sweet malts, resin, raisin, some port notes, bit od warming alcohol, slight medicinal, no hops, slight hint of smoke.
Taste - Caramel and toasted malts, molassess, spicy hops, post raisin, slight pepper, slight medicinal, smooth complex but not overtly strong. Well balanced
Palate - Dry on palate, hint of sherry in the finish. Moderate carb, smooth, medium body. 
Overall - One of the best bottled Scottish beers Ive tried. The Jacobite is bit more complex with its herbal notes. A superb strong ale, with complex but understated flavours.

More dry theand sessionable than a typical strong ale or barely wine.It has the classic sweet caramel malt taste but you get english some spice a small note of tang or citrus barely along with an earthyness to it maybe from the hops , a bit of a mineral like taste also with some dark fruit,keep thinking raison with a bit of chocolate,finishes fairly clean dry and abrubtly.Noticing a more woody like earthy aftertaste also.
 Aroma is similar in taste but pick up more in taste than aroma.Smooth slick sweet with a balancing dryness very soft mild bitterness leaving notes of dry chocolate caramel raison sweetness with a remaining earthy softmild bitterness.

11.2 oz bottle to a pint glass.  Pours dark chocolate with very small off white head, really almost none at all.  I get chocolate, coffee, slightly bread malt.  Very smooth and sweet, no bitterness at all.  I like it, a very pleasant surprise.
Svag doft av körsbärskärna. Skummar lite. Smakar honung, torkad frukt, marsipan, körsbär. Bra balans och hyfsat komplex smakbild. Riktigt god.

Ottima davvero questa strong proveniente dalla terra del kilt, tutto bene dallaspetto, allaroma di caffè, resine e leggera prugna, lascia un palato davvero contento con retrogusto finale di caffè, bene.
Very nice Scottish Ale. It resembles a Belgian/Trappist ale "8" or "10". Pours a dark rich caramel and tastes the same. No bitterness, lightly carbonated

Bouteille de 33cl. Bière brune foncée,  la mousse est épaisse et elle forme de grosses bulles. Le nez est de caramel. La bouche est soyeuse, ronde, agréable avec de bon goût de caramel, de malt crystal, plus sur le coté malt que houblon.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2011 (Bottled) Not as soulful as I  was expecting but its cool .  the  nose has the most heart . rich malts..some dark fruit textures  and oakiness ...classy fragance .... Flavours are more measly ..nice smoked notes from the oak casks though ... but this beer needs a richer soul ...

AROMA: dark chocolate, hint of espresso, light caramel
APPEARANCE: dark brown, clear, pours brown frothy head that disappears quickly
TASTE: light sweetness, lightly bitter, little bit savoury
PALATE: full body, thick feel almost creamy, lively, long finish going from bitter to leaving light sweetness in on the lips
OVERALL: one of my favourite Scottish ales, has almost the qualities of a Belgian Trappist (still lacks the balance of flavours)

Bottle from Waitrose. Pours a dark ruby colour with a beige head that dies away quickly. Aroma of alcohol, raisins, caramel, cereal, chocolate and roasty malt. Flavours of raisins, caramel and barley. Alcohol is fairly upfront. Some lingering alcohol hum also. OK.
Bottle. Cola and cinnamon aroma. Dark brown red appearance. Coffee, bittersweet taste. Quite nice.

Deep dark reddish brown, nice two-finger white head that dissipated to a swirly film, and decent lace. Rich malt nose with dark fruit, mostly figs, butterscotch, and a hint of licorice. Chewy bread-like malt flavors with a mild dark-fruit sweetness that features raisins and figs, slightly warming alcohol, and something like the Scottish shortbread cookies you get from Starbucks. Medium to full body, minimal carbonation, creamy smooth mouthfeel, and a very nice doughy bread-like finish. I really enjoyed this.
Pours a deep brown, clear, little to no head. Nice subtle aroma. Tastes like a super smooth, sophisticated Bass. Very nice.

Bottle at home. Dark brown pour, medium beige head. Raisin, caramel & some coffee on the nose. Palate is rich yet balanced - chocolate, raisin, liquorice maybe, with a surprising and wonderful treacle/alcohol warmth on the finish. Seriously impressed by this, and its right up my street. Yum.
330ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dark caramel with a medium head.  Aroma has raisin, thick treacle and a touch of mint.  Taste has raisin to start.  Treacle on the finish with a little alcohol.
Clear dark ruby red with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and dried fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. 050711

In bottle. Poured a beautiful, short-lived creamy head. Subtle aroma, definite malt notes but a nice understated nose. Medium-dark caramel brown, great medium mouth feel, distinct nutty and caramel plus some woody flavors detected. Crisp letoff with a moderate tang of not particularly bitter hops, left me wanting another one! Absolutely a "do again."

The look : Brown amber in color with a ring of foam.  The nose : Lovely fruits, cake and toasted malts.  The taste : Soft caramel, chocolate notes and macereted fruits.  The mouthfeel: Medium to full body with soft carbonation.  Good oily texture.  The finish :  Malty and fruity with a touch of tasty alcohol.

Bottled. Hazy cola colour, minimal head. Aroma rich in malts, full of toffy and slightly toasted/buttery breadiness. Sweetness and some sourness of ripe berries, sharp some licorice. Intense taste, woody dry touch. Toffy maltiness, sweetish berries. Light roastedness in the finish with a hint of chocolate. Soft palate, medium body, low in carbonation. Rich, intense and very drinkable.

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks Oren. Deep brown color with a bit of beige foam. Malty aroma with caramel, lots of nuts and some toastiness. Rather sweet malty flavor with nuts, caramel, biscuits and a drier finish with light bitterness, slightly herbal. Medium-bodied, rounded mouthfeel. A well-made beer - very malty but not overly sweet.

Appearance:  dark cola brown, small head shrinking to a soapy collar.  Aroma: vinous, boozy notes of prunes, cherries, raisins, red grapes, molasses and brown sugar.  Taste: brown sugar, caramel, toffee, brown bread, whisper of pine.  Finish: dry yet syrupy, with a little toasty sweetness.   Notes: Aroma seemed as if it would be a big, boozy, winey blast of fruity, alcohol-laden sweetness.  Flavors were much more of a semi-sweet doppelbock.  Palate was flat and sryupy.  Just didnt do it for me.

Pours brown-amber and transparent with a decent off-white head; nose is strongly oaked but not in an unpleasant way, with some hops and maple syrup in the background. Flavor and palate are both very soft. The flavor is best described as "earthy", with wooden and herbal hints coming out without a specific dominating flavor. Hops are light and balance the modest maltiness well. Finish is dry and slightly herbal. Not quite excellent but a solidly good beer.

Bottled. A dark chestnut colored beer with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of over ripe fruits, dusty hops, caramel, and alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of alcohol, over ripe fruits, spices, malt, and caramel, leading to a dry almost woody finish.

bottle, 033. Deep brown with gentle carbonation and  tight  head. 
Coffe hops and chocolate in aroma.

Note: stranissima inglese: molta schiuma ed molti aromi sprigionati allolfatto..sembra lanello di congiungione tra belgio e uk.

Chevy Chase, DC 330ml ($5.49): Pours brownish red with a rather small white head. Caramel, cake (I cant believe someone else described this aroma as cake), plenty of malts, biscuit, fruit, and some other fancy shmancy things. Incredibly drinkable and makes me want to drink all of it. Extremely well-balanced. Some hop bitterness and a modicum of astringency. A teeny-weeny bit of sugar, but not on the sweet side. An excellent beer, which I wish was cheaper than it is.

Bottle from Nelson Wines. It pours hazy dark brown with a red hue and a thin fizzy white head. The nose is sweet caramel, dried fruit, milk chocolate and toffee. The taste is vanilla, caramel, wood, liquorice, toffee, leather, smoke, tobacco, lactose, plum, dried cherry and milk chocolate, with a fruity finish.Very well balanced. A bit like a Scotch Ale-Belgian dubbel cross. High quality stuff.

The color is pretty, a dirty dark red that turns amber in the light, but the head too quickly retreats to the unwanted "Thin Doughnut" position.  Smells Scottish, for damn sure, cakelike with earthy funk underneath.  Starts moderately sweet, yet develops a biscuits-n-butter character that bleeds into a dry, whisky-soaked finish.  Lax carbonation means the flavors linger on the palate like a barrel of Scotch, thick and easy to drink.  (3/16/09)
Grassy cola aroma. Medium brown colour, not much head. Strong sweet grassy cola flavour. Smooth & oily. Quite unusual this one.
caramel, raisin, woody, brown, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, great brew.

Pours a very dark orangey brown with a short lived white head. Aroma is overripe fruit and sherry with hints of liquorice. Taste is sweet fruity malt slightly roasted with some distant caramel and spices. Overall flavour is slightly more akin to sherry than ale. Feels lovely and soft in the mouth. Great alround ale.

Deep brown beer with gentle carbonation and a tight tan head. Fairly sweet ale with complex malty notes and a fruity finish with lingering ghost of bitter hops. Very easy drinking but you can taste the alcohol long after the beer sweetness has faded.

A: The pour is dark amber in color with a smallish khaki colored head.

S: A really nice nose on this one. Sweet caramel and toffee all the way through with a hint of vanilla. Toasted bread and molasses give an extra bit of maltiness. A rather simple aroma, but quite good.

T: There is a hint of booze, but otherwise its a rather nice combination caramel and toffee. Some more of the bread and toast character, but it is a touch watery at times. Maybe some brown sugar.

M: Medium in body with a low to medium level of carbonation.

O: Overall pretty nice. A bit simple to me, but I liked what it had to offer.
Slightly burnt aroma, the flavor is warming with a slight alcohol kick and good malts.  A good English Strong Ale.
A very nice, east to drink ale.  Very smooth.  The flavor a muted and not very complex, but it doesnt need to be.  My first tasting from this brewer and I certaily will look for more.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2014 Pours a deep redish brown with a tan head. Aroma of ripe fruits, caramel, light rum and some toffee chocolate. Taste of ripe plums and other sweeter fruits, liquor filled chocolate and some woody sourness at the end.

Bottle; Dark Brown/Amber Pour. Off White/Beige head with decent retention and very light spotty lacing. The dark fruits really come out as this brew warms on the nose. Heavy on the malt side, obviously, while the creaminess from the head, which is quite nice. Cheese, and earthiness is present but beyond that, it seems a bit on the simple side - the dark fruits are more impressive on the nose, really.
Has most of the qualities that youd want in a Scottish Ale.  Nice dark brown color.  Flavor is a good balance of malt and hops with more on the malt side.

pours dark murky brown with floating chunks of yeast - yum, no head. tons of caramel malts, burnt wood, raisins, figs, aged malts, some spices, hint of vanilla, warming alcohol. very soft carbonation, medium to full body. very good brew. more of an old ale.

Serving: 330 ml. bottle from Chips Wine & Beer Market. 
It pours a sort of ruddy dark brown with a good bit of clarity and a small, foamy, white head.  The nose has a good bit of raisin and leans heavily on the malt.  Not surprisingly, the flavor carries the same with a bit of darker caramel malt.  Not much in the way of bitterness at all.  Medium bodied with average carbonation leading to a medium, raisin finish.  Not half bad.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark amber color withsmall off white head. Aroma is very malty, with lots of dark fruit, some oak, caramel and a breadiness. Flavor is of the dark fruit, a butter scotch note, caramel and bready malts, oak and a subtle rye bread note. The body is medium with a creamy and slightly dry mouthfeel. Overall a nice mild and malty brew.

Bottle @Maltainen Riekko. Poured brown color with a white head, nice lacing. Aroma is dark fruits, raisin and yeast. Flavor is also quite complex, same fruitiness, wood and malt, finish is quite dry, flavor stays quite long in the mouth. Really enjoyable.

33cl bottle. amber to copper and almost red in colour. some lace. Aromas are nutty, malted, some oak and has a slight prune like quality to it. some chocolate as well. Displays good complexity. palate is medium bodied, woody, almost tannic, malted and chocolate notes and some spices as well.very interesting but somehow it finishes light. A definite beer for the cellar.
Absolute ecstasy ... everything is perfect even better when conditioned in bottle. I had 2003 and it was like a cognac of beers. Amazing

Dark hazy brown, thin creamy tan head. Complex aroma of cherry, dark fruits, molasses, tobacco, smokey malts, soy. Taste is sweet, some earthy bitterness on the finish.  Body is a little thin. God, this high life I just took a swig of really tastes like shit now.

I wasnt very impressed. The flavor was so light I found myself repeatedly sipping it and pausing just to get a better idea of what I was drinking. The taste is mildly sweet, with a light kick of alcohol on top. As for aroma, it didnt strike me as much more than a mild breadiness, with the lightest hint of cherry.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2011 1 June 2011, bottle. deep mahogany colour, clear no bubbles. nose is oatmeal, alcohol,  red fruit, and caramel malt. full body and mildly fizzy. nice strong ale. creamy oatmeal and alcohol, some oaky notes. very sweet and malty. 

(original rating 31 Jan 2011 - 4, 3, 5, 4, 12 = 2.8) deep amber colour, clear w/ steady bubbles
Nose is dry nutty malt
full body and moderately fizzy. not syrupy and carbonation gives it a short, sharp finish
Taste is a nutty amber ale but with an alcohol presence that balances what i typically find to be a blase style

Traquair House Ale pours a dark chestnut color that is virtually impenetrable by light. The head developed one finger thick even with an extremely aggressive pour. There was minimal lacing and short retention.

My nose is picking up on a handful of similar aromas: roasted malt, toffee, caramel, and molasses. They all balance each other out quite well. 

The taste was not as loaded as the aroma. I only really notice roasted and nutty caramel and toffee. It is surely less complex then smelling the beer let on. 

The mouthfeel is quite light and carbonation is low to medium. The alcohol content of 7.2% is not any more noticeable than a beer with 5%. It goes down quite easy.

The individual aspects of this beer are less than the sum of its parts. My general overall impression of this beer is quite positive. It has very complimentary flavors, smells, and mouthfeel that combine for a very enjoyable drink.

Chestnut brown-amber body and root beer frothed head. Feintly nut brown malt nose with sweet malt tips and accompanied by some staleness that probably is the result of aging and early effects of oxidation. Aged-brown malt body with winces of cider brown sweetnes and some residual caramel sugar on the finish.

*Newbie rating* Trappist glass from bottle. Aroma - Caramel, bit of raisin slight vanilla hint. Appearance - Dark, ruby with a fast disappearing light tan head. Taste - Toffee & hint of citrus. Palate -  Soft carbonation.

Bottle around Christmas time. Pours a clear red/brown with a medium tan head. Malty and super caramelly nose with some chocolate and cherry notes. Caramel malt flavor with cherry and a bit of booze before a peaty and chocolatey finish.

Date: 7/11/2010   Source:Other   Malty caramel with some peaty notes in aroma. Clear amber dark brown with little head. Very malty flavor with lots of dark sugars. Hints of plums and smoke. Medium to full body with hint of alcohol warming. Malty, toasty, roasty, medium finish.

330 mL bottle.  (bb Dec 2016).  Hazy, rusty brown with very little head.  Lotsa molasses and dark fruit (dates, figs) in the aroma.  The flavour is quite complex, with caramel, dark fruit, cola, and licorice.  Somehow, its not overly sweet.  Low carbonation, heavy mouthfeel.  Good stuff.
Ale decisa ma non estrema, proviene dalla Scozia, anzi più precisamente dal frigo di Corkscrew che me la portò questestate per una delle solite grigliate devastanti.

(bottle) pours a slightly hazy ruby-brown colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of heavy raisins and light milk chocolate, with notes of dark fruit and bread dough. flavour is mostly the same, with lots of dark fruit, bread and underlying hints of sherry and alcohol, rather sweet. medium to heavy body with lively carbonation.

From bottle. Malty rich nose, root beer, and spice notes. Roasty and chocolatey, with a bit of plum. Light hoppy notes. Dark brown black clear with thin head. Medium-heavy watery body with medium-high carbonation and light warming. Nice rich malt sweetness to start, light roasted barley, candi sugar. Much like a Belgian abt or rich Dubbel. Light hoppy dry bitterness in finish with clean sweet malt nutty after. Tasty stuff.

Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with no head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, caramel and some notes of roasted barley. The flavor is close to the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall an average beer.

An odd inclusion at a recent tasting of winter beers, as its more a scotch ale than a winter. Still, a very good beer - despite the high content, not overly alcohol-y in taste. Very balanced and quite drinkable.

A: Pours an impenetrable deep chestnut, although the head is quite small even on a hard pour. Spotty lacing as I make my way down the snifter.

S: Toffee, butterscotch, light caramel, molasses, and hints of diacetyl are what I notice immediately. Everything is well integrated, though a bit lacking in the deeper caramelized malts that I would expect from such a noted Scotch Ale producer. 

T: A bit of a letdown after the nose. Not nearly as complex, as a bit of roasted nutty caramel takes over the beer, leaving a bit of lingering bitterness. Hints of butter.

M: Quite thin, especially for the style and alcohol content. This has the mouthfeel of a light Scottish Ale rather than the big boy that its supposed to be. Fairly low carbonation. Not much of an alcohol bite at all.

D: Quite drinkable given the lack of alcohol presence in the taste, and the general smooth drinkability that comes from a thinner mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-29-2010

Pours a ruddy brown with fine suspended particles and a creamy beige head that reduces to a thin skin at the surface. The nose is big and malty with dark (yet bright) fruit, sweet baking spices, and peat notes. Medium-bodied and slick with distinct mineral-water quality to the mouthfeel. The flavor strikes me more as a wee heavy versus the flavor profile Ive gotten from other ESAs: peaty malt, a touch of dark fruit and some spicy/peppery and ashy notes conclude with a drying moderately astringent, yet pleasant, finish. This bottle being a couple years old, I also get a touch of cardboardy oxidation, but its still a pretty solid beer. Im nowhere near as enthusiastic about this one as I was their Traquair Ale, but if you enjoy scotch ales, Id give this one a try.

330ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a thick and lacy head. the aroma consists of vanilla, woody, caramel, chocolate, raisin, and a little licorice. The taste is fairly sweet with little bitterness and a somewhat dry finish.
Pours brown with no head. Aroma is roasted caramel and fruity notes. Flavour is roasted caramel, fruity notes, light dust and plum.

maybe the style just isnt really my thing. from my notes: flat, thin, bready. 

not going to revisit this one.

Pours clear dark ruby brown with minimal off white head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel, fidges, coffee, roasted malts and vanilla. Very pleasant. Malty lean mouthfeel. Slightly thin body. Acidy fruity, malty, dry, hoppy flavor with tones of perry. Flat fruity palate. Finishes short lived tart hoppy and fruity.

In short: A mostly typical fruity and peaty strong enlgish dark ale.  Nice beer.
How: Bottle 330ml.  Consumed moderately fresh about 6 months after receiving through private importation
The look: Clear dark burgundy body topped by a beige ring of foam
In long: Nose of dark fruits and coca-cola.  Taste is raisin pie, fresh dark fruits, dry tree leafs, forest floor, toffee, peat, tobacco, sweet potatoes (really!).  Very mild fruity bitterness.  Baked dark fruits in the after-taste.  Body is smooth and full and the carbonation is lots of soft bubbles.  Easy to drink beer that went down very quickly.  Sessionnable 7.2% beer.  The type of beer I could drink on a daily basis if my girlfriend would let me.  Im not saying that my girlfriend is a control freak.  Well, not without her permission.

Pour is dark brown like cola and has an off white head that fades to film on top. Aroma is burnt toffee and caramel malt and a little maple syrup. Taste is more malt that comes sweet with some spices as well. Palate is thin to medium feel that is fizzy and chaulky.
Deep brown with no head. Aroma is honey, wood, malt... very interesting. Flavor is coffee, bread, caramel malt, [and metal?]. An interesting brew.

Bottle. Clear dark reddish brown with a small pale beige head. Heavy aroma of toffee, prunes, dates. Syrupy mouthfeel at first. Very sweet with toffee and dark fruits. Finish is slightly drying and woody but somehow lightens the sweetness a lot more than expected.

Bottle. Pours dark red, cloudy.  Beige head.  Aroma is caramel/maltiness, some alcohol, dark fruits with hoppiness underneath.  Flavor is malty, sweet, dark fruitness.  Medium bitterness but well balanced.  Good beer.

Poured a clear dark brown with not much head.  Aroma is quite complex with caramel, nuts, honey, and brown sugar.  Alcohol is slightly noticeable.  Taste is also complex: nutty upfront with caramel.  Transitions into a sweet and slightly fruity finish.  Finish also has dark fruits and vanilla.  Overall very crisp and drinkable.  Alcohol is not noticeable in the taste.  Well balanced and good.  Yummy.
Had this in the bottle.  Pours brown.  Id say that it was unremarkable, but I would drink it again.

Assaggiata in bottiglia da 33 cl.
Aspetto ambrato molto scuro, schiuma bassa quasi come una porter. al palato è decisa e gustosa, con un aroma di affumicato e caramello; si sente bene lalcool. Finale amarognolo che non mi è parso lunghissimo. Nel complesso una buona birra forse non da pasto ma quasi da "meditazione"

Pours a cola-brown. Darker than expected. Aroma is sweet and light. Flavor is bold and oaky with toasted nut (chestnut and walnut) notes. Mouthfeel is smooth with a nice level of carbonation for the style. Solid certainly, but the Jacobite is superior.

Dirty brown pour, exquisite off-white head, clinging to brandy snifter. Nice legs, smokey alcohol nose, hint of dark fruit, maybe date. Sweet, wood, biscuit, and alcohol flavor. A bit of tart on the thin finish. Slight bitter lingering on my tongue. Really changes as it gets some air. Tasted from the bottle @ 60F.

330 ml bottle @ Olutkellari Helsinki. Rated @ 24.1.2010.
Pours a clear brown colour with a small creamy head. Malty on the nose with salty licorice notes. Flavour of slightly roasted malts, licorice, dark fruits and syrup. Sweet malty finish. Easy to drink. Decent.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 Aroma is nice, dark fruit. Earthy, oak. Appearance is very dark brown almost black. Small head. Not impresive. Looks like a glass of Coca-cola. Taste is dark fruits first, then coffee, chocolate, then oak. English esters present but fighting through all the other flavors. Many strong flavors, but not overly complex. Palate is medium. Oak and roastiness linger. Slight hotness, but barely. Overall, I like this beer. It is different and enjoyable. Very smooth. Not a typical strong ale as it brings in more roasty flavors than I am used to. Definatelly worth a try, but I will not buy again.

Bottle from Nelson Wines, Merton. Dark brown pour with a light beige head. Raisins, chocolate, nuts and a little vanilla nose. Malty flavours of toffee, raisins, caramel, vanilla, chocolate. Very smooth. Nicely balanced. Dry, sweet finish. Nice.

Bottle. Hazy red colour with a weak, off white head. Aroma has a fruity and wine-like base coupled with some alcohol and a little caramel-ish malts. Some plums as well. The whole deal is finished off nicely by fresh hops. Taste is very sweet with berries and wine, coupled with the sweet malt. A little fresh mint and spices can are traceable as well. Also a tiny bit of smoke and faint roast, providing a modest bitterness. Some faint, dry hops in the finish as well. Low carbonation, medium-big body, medium-long duration.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2015 very malty, smokey, and slicker than snot on a glass eye!!!  this is a great beer.  one of the best of this style, i highly recomend it.  its a little pricey for the tiny bottle, but totally worth it.
2015 - bigger size for roughly the same price I paid for 10 oz before.  takes a while to open up...next time Ill just slightly chill it.  Too cold, its good.  Near room temp its still phenomenal.

Lovely mahogany colour with a big frothy head and lace. The beer look fantastic. Rich malt aroma with pleasant fruit hints. Delicious full bodied malt flavour. Rich fruity, roasted texture. Bitter yet keeps a lovely rich smooth finish. Quality beer.
330 ml bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $5.49 Excellent!
UPDATED: JAN 15, 2011 Bottle. Dark brown with a small head. Licorice, caramel, dried fruits. This is nice.

Pours a deep mohogany with red tint. Head is full beige but was fleeting. Massive aroma of fig, prune and date. Chocolate as well. Very nice, rich nose. Mouthfeel is medium with slight slickness. Chocolate with some malty sweetness. Like a winter warmer. I would pair this with a molten lava chocolate cake.

A: pours a deep rich mahogany color with a nice tan colored head on top. good retention rate, with a moderate amount of lacing.

S: huge malty nose. some nice red licorice notes, hints of clove and a light banana tone. some earthy notes...almost oak-like.

T: wonderful flavors. this is what a wee heavy should taste like. robust malts supply the major caramel notes to this. light hints of licorice, clove, and some light banana flavors. small notes of pipe tobacco also come into play.

M: relatively smooth, especially for the higher ABV. medium bodied. solid carbonation level. great palate.

330 ml bottle from Premier Wine & Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a chesnut brown with small tan head.  Lightly roasty aroma of raisin, toffee and yeast.  Taste is mildly roasty with toffee, yeast, a hint of chocolate.  Prominent, somewhat dry bitterness in finish.  Quite good.

Bottle.  Pours dark ruby-colored, nearly brown, with  a small light brown head.  Aromas of caramel, molasses, plum, English malt, lots of toffee, and brown sugar.  Flavor is sweet roasty malt, rich toffee, cocoa, and a coffee finish, followed by a plum and raisin aftertaste.  Mouthfeel is thick, creamy, and a touch warming.  Pretty nice stuff.

330ml bottle. Pours a very deep amber/orange with short tan head that leaves very little lace. Nose dominated by whole grain toast with a little sweetness and some barnyard notes. Theres a little fruit on the palate but not much. Its still dominated by that toasted grain with a slightly sweet finish.

Pours a dark brown hue with a thin creamy caramel head. Smells of sweet caramel, raisin and roasted malts. Taste semi sweet with a caramel, toffee and raisin background. Has a flavorless finish with almost no aftertaste. Good but not great.
UPDATED: SEP 26, 2016 I loved this. Roasted/a bit smoky/a bit peaty I didnt see it in the other reviews but I picked up just a bit of sour tartness that I quite liked. Well done.  Serving: Bottle

Very heavy, earthy aroma from the barrel. Smells more like other barrel aged liquor than beer. Nice head on pour, Quite dark, brown on the edges, maintains some fine lacing but mostly just around the edge. Very soft on the tounge, A shallow sweetness met evenly with the yeast flavour, it finishes with the barrel and goes on for a bit. This is quite nicely balance, just a bit of sharpness at the end of it all to pique your tounge. I also just mowed the lawn so this goes great!

Bottle 33cl. A clear amber brown ale with almost no head. Smell is very caramel and sirupy. Aroma is very nice with spicy, chocolate and caramel notes with a good malty body which is quite sweet. Finish is nice and spicy with fruit notes such as cassis and banana, some smoked notes too.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear dark brown color with a thin off-white head leaving some lacing. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits, chocolate and licorice. Flavor is creamy bittersweet with some spices, toffee and nuts. Quite bitter in the finish. Full body, creamy texture and low carbonation. Nice brew.
Bottle from drowland.  Brown pour with a white head.  Aroma is bacon, smoke, molasses, and alcohol.  Taste is smoke, chocolate, nuts, and alcohol.

Bottle courtesy of Fratto via drowland. Dark red color that is very clear. Tan bubbly head. Smell is pipe tobacco, leather and some cologne. Taste is a bit smacky.  Dry malts with a bitter finish that lingers.

De couleur rousse-cuivrée, elle est limpide. Légers arômes de malt, dépices et de jello aux cerises-fraises. Légèrement piquante en bouche, on perçoit vite la douceur et lépaisseur de la bière. Notes de fruits rouge et de malt et une touche dalcool en finale.

Bottle.  Pours dark mahogany with a dark, thin head.  Aroma is sweet, fruity (raisins?), and alcohol.  Flavor is sweet, malty, bit of chocolate and smoke -- and some rock sugar?!  Actually a bit thin, I thought.  Good, but not for $6 a bottle.
Bottle, pours dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel, oak, chocolate, berries and nuts. Flavour of bittersweet chocolate, oak, nuts, and some spice. Very nice.
Dark brown, thin tan head, little lacing.  Notes of raisin, malt, and spice.  Taste is bittersweet chocolate and plum.  Creamy.

33cl bottle: Pours dark brown with a vanishing, off-white head. Raisiny, sherry-like aroma, very rich and deep, a little chocolatey and smokey. The best thing about this is the lovely, creamy and fine-bubbled mouthfeel, with lots of caramel and dried fruits in the flavour. Bittersweet finish. A beer best enjoyed on stormy autumn evenings.

Dark brown pour with a ruby hue light off white head light lacing ..... caramel and nutty aroma ..... taste of nuts and berries, caramel and a little oaky ..... sweet and medium bodied, smooth and a little creamy ....  no trace of abv .....  good balance of flavors and sessionable

330 ml bottle drank at Brouhaha in Montreal, May 30, 2010. Dark Burgundy, little head. Sweet aroma of malted barley, slightly spicy. Not strong malted barley taste, hints of fruits, dry bitterness. Good but not spectacular!


.
