There is also a touch of soy sauce amongst the smoke and peat. Hints of the 7.2 % alcohol sneak through at time. Smooth taste. Mouthfeel is a little bit thin and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
A very malty choc flavoured brew. Love the full maltiness of the flavour and the pleasing mouthfeel. Mild flavour of raisins and plums.

Pours a thin ruby brown with very little head or carbonation.  Complex chocolate plum and brown sugar aroma leads into a light body with a variety of flavors including dark fruits and soy sauce.  The body is a little watery, but overall satifying.  The alcohol is very well hidden.  Finishes dry and woody with a faint touch of milk chocolate.

Dark maroon. Tan head dissipates rapidly but leaves persistent lace anyway. Complex; raisiny, malty, smoky, and woody flavors are apparent, along with a slight bitterness. Full-bodied. Smells more of malt and dried fruit than of hops. After a weekend of crappy lagers this was much needed, and on sale at Donderbak's for $3 per bottle, I'm going to stock up...

Dark brown in color, with a tinge of red.  Very little head and carbonation.  Malty and somewhat smokey taste.  Some of the fruitiness and oak flavor that you might associate with an oak aged wine.  Very interesting, very good, but a little expensive for what it is.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2005 Deep garnet-brown hue.  Sticky off-white head.  Nose of malts, light smokiness.  Big malt body, sweet, cherries, chocolate, caramel, well rounded with a smokiness in the backdrop.
deep brown. Malt aroma. Slightly sweet malt with smoky wood tones and distinct warm alcohol flavor (like a brandy). Nice mild hops finish. Excellent, but very pricey.

pours a murky brown with a tan head. aroma is a little hoppy but mostly fruity. flavor is very malty with a woody flavor from the oak cask fermenting. has kind of a sweet apple taste to it. very interesting and good.

Dark malt fruit aroma, prune especially noticeable. Dark fruitiness also strong on the palate but has a clean fresh minty balance in the second half and drying hoppiness in the finish. Licorice notes appear in the aftertaste.
Tastes like Oak barrels and smoked planks of wood. Deep rich red/black color. Malty textures with a hint of tannic acid.
Good Scottish ale. Smokey malt and oak flavor.  Finishes with a smooth bitter flavor.

Interesting. Woody aroma. Deep brown color. Little head that was gone almost immediately. Initial flavor was sweet but then it started to focus into more of a bar-b-que flavor. medium to light body. Short finish.
Ruby colour with disappearing head. The taste is very complex: it's malty, with light traces of caramel and wine flavour and it's a bit salty. Very particular, but not really my favourite beer.

This almost-black beer has ruby glints and a nice, medium head. The nose is of coffee, burnt grains, raisin and light alcohol. The palate is richly malty and accentuated by caramely and chocolatey nuances. As the palate moves toward the finish there is a moment of winey-like fruit which results in a very port-like beer. The finish is long and nutty.
Amber coloured beer with a medium creamy head. Fruity and woody aroma. Rather sweet, sharp taste. Bitter aftertaste.

This is one of the ales that I have had in the past, forgot about because of the price, but wanted to revisit. Dark brown thick (hazy and chunky) liquid with a thin lid of beige bubbles that disappear quickly.  Strong malt aroma reminiscent of many eisbock/barley wines.  Initial malt and peat float through the mouth merging with caramel, toffee, and smokey salt pork.  "This is a hearty brew made to be imbibed while wearing a kilt with smoked meats and sausages grilled over an open flame and brandishing a tankard and grunting manly thoughts." - Oops, maybe a little carried away there.  Brandy qualities come out as this one warms.  Thick malty flavors continue through to the finish.  Ugh - Beer  Good!
Deep brown with reddish hints, thin but long lasting beige head.  Aroma of caramel, malts, chocolate hints.  Sweet, nutty, a bit oaky, slides on a thin acidity and finishes on a dryer, woody note.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2004 Malt! Yeah its sweet but not cloying. The sweetness seems to be balanced out by the alcohols dryness and a mild nutty flavor. Just a great beer in this style but at the money it cost it will remain a rare treat

dark brown in color, nice cream head that lasts.  Aroma, is nutty, slightly smokey and some fruit notes as well.  The flavor is complex, starts nutty, the middle has some sweet fruit like flavors, nice hop presence helps to finish great.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2003 THe best Scottish ale that I"ve ever had by a long shot, and certainly one of the best beers period.  How bad do I wish this wasn"t $6 a bottle.  Malt, Malt, Malt.  Hides its alcohol content completely.  I figured this was a 5% ABV.  In my mind this is almost a perfect beer if you like sweet malty brews.  No hints of smoke found in some Scottish Ales.
Bottle.  Brown color with a laced tan head.  A lot of malt in the nose, some nuttiness, caramel, and an overall earthy tone.  Like a good cigar, it leaves your mouth full of primal flavors.
fermenting in uncoated wooden vats imparts a touch of a oaky flavor to this unique ale.
dark brown, thin off white head.  malty, raisiny, toffee-ish aroma.  smooth for its abv.  nice dark fruity flavours with some herby undertones.  quite good.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 Head began nice and frothy but settled thin like the continents seen from space...Pounds of cherry carmel malts & a tad of chocolate too
AAhhhh!!!! Metallicness...BLAH!!!!...tryi to see past the metalicness..some chewing tobacco spit..cherries stripped of all sweetness..alcohol burn...Metallicness subsides in time, but I won't forget it was there..tons of not-so-fresh bitterness lings around to..also, the strong presence of alcohol kills the flavor of food... Not one of my favorites
Very odd after taste.  I didnt like this partcular ale, but some people obviously do.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2012 Bottle... This beer rocks!... An incredible, sparkling dark amber hue with a small, creamy, off-white head. Mostly diminishing. The aroma is thick with malt and caramel. Chocolate and toffee notes. Plenty of alcohol in the nose as well. Full-bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel. Heavily malty and lightly tangy up front, the flavor is a swirl of alcohol, dark chocolate and caramel flanked by perfectly balanced malt and hops on the backside. A lengthy, somewhat dry and bitter finish with undertones of sweet, sweet alcohol. A very nice Scotch ale. World class beer! I look forward to trying the Jacobite ale as well.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 
Aug, 2003 There is a lot going on in this dark ruby ale - the pale and dark malts combining with the East Kent Goldings to produce a range of flavours from which you can take your pick, but fresh anthracite coal with a splash of breast milk from an alcoholic mother mixed with coca-cola is what I found. The hops are over stewed and over used, resulting in a stodgy bitterness. That stodgy bitterness is the only moment of balance I found, blending, as it does, rather nicely with the stodgy damp wood of the malt. There are sharper features to counter the stodge, but these tend to be chocolate tinged, which doesnt really add anything of interest. Overall, a rather heavy going and awkward beer which has plenty of flavours but without control or style. The brewerys Jacobite is more controlled and delightful; indeed, something of a masterpiece. But this house ale feels crudely thrown together like a homebrew. Theres flavours here, and some will like it purely because they can taste something - but those who like their beer flavours to draw an intelligent picture rather than just be slapped on the canvas, will be disappointed.  [2.7] 
Sept, 2012 330ml brown glass bottle from Dobbies. There are flavours here for sure - treacle and spices and some alcohol warmth. The fermenting is done in wooden vats, so there should be character as well, but the filtering takes the edge off that - which is a shame. This is an OK beer, and theres much to like - though not as much as one would want to like. I am enjoying this much more than I apparently did back in 2003, but theres still a feeling that the ingredients or the brewing method is not doing as much as it could to make the most of the potential. Bottle conditioning would help, though I suspect theres something else. Fermenting temperature a little too low perhaps?  [3.5]

Had a few bottles of this tonight.  Pleasant nose of spice, dried fruit (raisin, date, etc.) 
pepper, anise, and alcohol.  Pours a dark ruby copper brown.  The huge rocky tan head is
tight but not fully lasting.  The lacing is good.  The brew initially tastes sweet with a very
warm alcoholic middle, and the finish is sweet as well with a port like quality.  The rich
full soft body is syrupy with a finish that feels alcoholic.  Makes a nice late night warmer
now that things are cooling off.  Reminds me of McEwans Scottish Ale.

the colour of a nice old piano, with a head the colour of the ivories. massively malty, chocolatey and fruity to start with, then someone flicks a switch and your mouth gets filled with liquorice, peppermint, ginger and mouthwash in general. one of the most powerfully flavourful beers ive had, but a bit too medicinal to want to drink a lot of.
Dark red body, off-white head, malty nose. Nice rich malty body with a hint of smoke toward the finish.

having tried the jacobite version prior to tasting this one, i was not all that impressed. pretty much a dressed down version of the jacobite ale. fruity, vinious aroma, lovely ruby brown color, but the FLAVOR just wasnt there.

this dark mohagony colored brew has a slightly sweet malty aroma with some fruity and spicy notes in the background.  the flavor is malty with a hint of smokey nut flavor and hops.  the beer is slightly dry with a bite of alcohol deep in the throat.
Malty and spicy. Maybe even a little bit of a caramel characteristic.  But at $5 for every 11.2oz, your going to have to take out a second mortgage just to get hammered.
Excellent example of a Scottich ale.  Malt aroma, in particular a hint of toasted malt.  Smooth, very clean flavor dominated by malt, with a hint of smoke.  Well-balanced bitterness.
Very malty, sweet aroma, but more mild malty taste with a hint of caramel. Very complex, almost wine-like flavor. Nice carbonation, and dry finish.
UPDATED: APR 14, 2004 Caramel aroma. Malty sweet flavor with hints of alcohol. Beautiful reddish-brown color. Dry finish with just the perfect amount of carbonation. Very refined, sophisticated beer.

Wow, what a surprising disappointment- Very odd grayish red-black color. Head was thin but lively. Nose of sweet port/sherry. Wood, licorice, raisins, chocolate. Slightly disappointing palete. Incredible dryness sets in at the last 1/5 of the glass.
nice chocolate color with malt aroma nice fruit and malt flavours  with a nice  warming finnish

Dark brown-ruby color. Weak beige head. Aroma is malty, fruity, with chocolate and tea notes.
Flavor is malty too with dried fruit tones, ending in a roasted and slightly smokey finish.
Medium bodied.

Dark reddish brown in color with a strong aroma of chocolate, raisins and alcohol.  The taste mimicked the smell.  This had way too much alcohol flavor for a 7.2% ABV beer.  It was out of proportion with the other flavors.  At $4 + per 11.2 ounce bottle, I dont think Ill ever try this again.
fantastic. exciting fruity aroma. dark brown, nearly opaque. mouthfeel very satisfying. sit back, and take your time.

dark brown body, no head - lowly carbonated.  very smooooth thick malt taste with some juicy flavors in there - maybe plum or prune.  medium dry finish, but the warmth of the alcohol stays a long time.  a good sipper.

Nice malty aroma, a dark brown/ruby color, and a thin head that dissapated until it eventually looked like flat Coca-cola.  Malty sweetness in the flavor, and very minimal hopping compared to what im used to in the Pacific Northwest.  Palate was actually fairly smooth, and could drink it again, but it cost  $5.50 a bottle here, so probably not.

Bottled. Deep chestnut colour, moderate head with good condition. Barley wine nose with hints of licorice and roast malts and  nostril stripping alcohol. Roast malt and coffee in the mouth and a good level of hoppiness that tasted a little like cascade but I cant be sure. Dry, roasty finish. This beer does not taste like its 7.2% abv and can easily catch you out
sweet smokey aroma, thick brown head, creamy mouthfeel, smokey roasted malty.

Had this as a birthday beer and enjoyed it very much.  It pour well and held its taste until I finished it.  The color was a dark brown and there was very little head when the beer was poured.  There was a strong smell of alchol but the taste of it was very mellow..

I just didnt go for this one. Out of the bottle I got a murky brown, headless concoction -  not flat or stale, though. Strong earthy chocolate-coffee aroma. Flavor continued the coffee-chocolate direction, also woody w. dried fruit and herbal elements. The strong bitter finish just didnt wash...it came on like a dessert beer and finished dirty and bitter. Not a favorite, will try again.
A beer with a thick head.  It has an overriding cocoa powder aroma and a chocolate flavour.  A very nice beer.

1/02 Bottled, unsure of date.  Nice dark-brown translucent color, with thinnish head.  Nose is very strong and whiskey/caramel scented.  Flavor just as powerful, with a slight smoky/mustiness that at first struck me as odd but later seemed right.  Earthy, oaky, darkly spicy/fruity (figs? cardamom? maybe even a hint of black pepper?); very complex and full; great body with a finish that might be just a bit too sour.  Just about as good as the Jacobite, Id say; wish this brewery was more widely distributed in the USA. 7/02 Alcohol a little too prominent in this sample; maybe a touch too bitter also.  Slightly less impressive 2nd time around, but still very good.
Dark coppper color.Aroma of toasted malt. Tastes rich and full. Excellent beer.
very vinous nose. too many malt flavors to count.  Deep brown and burgundy color.   complex malty flavor that makes my head spin.  Brillance.
not too strong but solid like pressed kief hash, and it did cause me to spill all over my rating sheet
Very complex, raisin/plum esters, alcohol very noticable, peat-smokiness good contrast to fruit overtones.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2015 Vanilla, chocolate and caramel with a touch of earthy smoke... A few dried fruit are found underneath... This is a good Scotch Ale, but nothing noteworthy these days (although it might be beautiful on cask)...
Sweet black currant-flavour. Some alcohol-flavour. The oak cask-fermentation gave me a headache! Nope, didnt like this one.

Beautiful dark red color, large head that quickly drops, strong malty aroma, roasty flavor, some caramel, very slightly smoky, medium body. I was expecting a little more body and a little less roastiness. Still, this is an excellent Scotch Ale.

Bought in 1985 and hidden in my cellar all those years. Alc % on the label: 6%. Overwhelming porto aroma. Carbonation has almost disappeared. Porto taste with blackcurrant, raisins and pure chocolate. A bit metallic and buttery aftertaste. A very special beer that has survived 17 years of storage under less than ideal circumstances well.
Sweet malts, full aroma, spicy finish. A full flavored, mild nosed Scottish Ale with some tobacco pepper back. Delicious and genteel.
I prefer the Orkney Skullsplitter, personally.  Decent flavor and very complex.  A bit bitter.  Strong and very malty.

Heady, indulgently fruity aroma.  About the darkest but still distinguishable red/brown color Ive seen.  Extremely fine carbonation, interesting effervescence for a beer of this style.  Served at approx. 60 F in a brandy snifter, Im convinced this is the way to go.  Slightly smoky, rich fruit flavor in the malt, and just a touch of light hops for the finish.  Overall, a bit on the sweet side, but well balanced.  Some alcohol to be noticed here, even though the % is lower than expected.  Definitely a terrific strong Scottish style ale, the most complex Ive had to date.
Smells like homemade wine. Looks like brewed ice tea. Strong and malty. Thick, good mouthfeel. Very nice.
Amazing!...Find it, but it, savor it.
Great drink. Warming, refreshing and the alcohol is well hidden. The aroma is breathtaking. I would recommend this to anyone.
Heavy, Malty big brew. Good with steak or any red meat.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2006 Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel), with notes of vanilla and sherry, hint of alcohol.
Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lighlty to moderately bitter, lightly acidic, lightly sweet. Medium body, watery
texture, lively carbonation. Doesnt do much for me, but who the hell knows how fresh it is?

This is a darn good ale and a fine Scottish ale.  Extremely malty and peaty in the nose and on the tongue.  Dry enough not to be cloying.  Very alcoholic, but it is well hidden and reminiscent of a fine barleywine.  Deep auburn to mahogony color with a medium sized, quickly dissipating head.  Very good.

Whoa Nellie!  Those Scots know how to put a wee bit of the Scotch whisky into their brew that truly sends a jolt into you, “Beam me up, Scotty!”  A beautiful rich, dark mahogany color, little to no head at all, and a very, very dry, mostly bitter malt taste, but it improves as it slowly unwinds to room temperature, this is almost like sipping a dry cognac, a drink for the purists, and a good winter warmer...

Peaty aroma and malty/smoky-sweet flavor.  As a hop-lover, I was a little put off by the flavor of this beer.  There was almost no head, the color was a lovely rich and welcoming brown.  The flavor was too malty for my taste, though.  Too jarring.

Wonderful sweet malty aroma, a wee bit of brandy sneaking through.  The flavor is rich and complex, the maltiness combined with fruitiness, mild smokiness and some chocolate.  Alcohol flavor shows through just a little bit.  Aftertaste a bit cloying, but otherwise an excellent beer.
Thick sweet malty low carbonatated creamy scottish great for sipping. Now if that isnt a great run-on of adjectives I dont know what is.
Damn fine ale.  One of the best scotch ales I have been privelaged to try.  Thick malt taste and molasses/carmel after taste.  Absolutely wonderful.  Even got some smokiness from it.

great scotch ale.
dark nutty brown , beige head. 
overpowering malt aroma that has notes of toffee, caramel and plums.
very rich taste. malt dominates. full flavor with many organic tsatessuch as wood, smoke and peat.
 smooth velvet palate with the alcohol content well hidden.

Deep garnet in color, the head beige, the lace adequate. Nose that of a fine brandy, with malts and a touch of caramel. Malt sweet at the front, the top light to medium, the finish is dry, nicely hopped, light to minimal carbonation. A quite drinkable beer, a pleasure to Whiff such a nose.
This beer has a fantastic burnt coffee and dark chocolate taste with a long dry finish.  Belgians would be proud of this.

Nice auburn color with a moderate head that fades pretty quickly.  Interesting scent on this one, with molasses, soy, maple syrup, spice, and who knows what else.  Flavor is of licorice, brown sugar, bread, caramel, and, again, who knows what else.  Enjoyed it, but, due to its complexity, need to revisit it to get a better handle on the flavors.
Good, thick malty beer.  Spicy with plums and figs.  Sweet finish.  Maybe I expected a little more out of this, but I couldnt help being a wee bit disappointed.
It has a deep woody/wine character to it.  Certainly a slow sipper.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2005 Brownred hue. Malty and spicy nose with a hint of almonds. The flavor is syrupy with toffee and chocolate tones and a large bitterness combined with some almond notes. It dies rather quickly. It will hoppefully grow with maturation. I have a few stored away and will return to them in a couple of years.
I feel this is a huge ripoff.  Maybe I cracked it open too warm, maybe the oak cask flavor, but this one did me wrong.  I prefer a Robert the Bruce or Old Jock any day.

Very, very good stuff.  Nice and dark, extremely malty, warming, thick, and with a slight madeira quality.  About as good as an ale can get.  My only complaint is, why $5 a bottle?  Its very good, but I feel that I am being taken advantage of when I buy this stuff.  Its like I can see someone at the brewery counting his money and laughing.  MacAndrews Scotch (now Stock) Ale is just about as good, and priced more reasonably.  I dont usually complain about a beers price, and will gladly pay $5 a bottle for something different, but this beer does not have any special characteristics to justify the steep price.  Its just very good, but there are other very good beers out there.  And the bottle isnt even 12 oz!  Rating down two points for being overpriced.
Dark nut brown. Very malty, and rich with notes of caramell, oak and smoke. Salty and well balanced.
UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Damn. This was good. Smooth flavors of caramel/butterscotch and the like. Very enjoyable.
Good scotch ale, nice dark fruit flavour, malty, chocolatey. A bit edgey on the finish, but it was a great beer.

Ill have to go back and give this a try sometime when I dont have a stuffy head. Though my taste was somewhat impaired, this stuff seemed pretty impressive: rich, smoky malts, spicy hop notes and a powerful bitterness.

Im giving it my first perfect score.
I was amazed at the wonderful malt
flavors, almost like a red wine.
Perfect balance, beautiful deep red/garnet
color.  Rich aroma  (yes, pretty close to the
SATB).  This was actually served to me at room
temp (note: *not* cellar temp, *room* temp) and
it was wonderful, with all the various flavor
notes at their best, showing off the amazing
complexity of this beer.
Updating with more specifics: Dark cloudy brown, with thick dense head.  Rich plummy aroma.  Flavor full of dark fruit, figs and plums.  Lingering warm and alcoholic finish.  Not as stunning as my previous tasting, but Ill leave the 5.0 score alone.
A damn fine beer. I expected a bit more.  But it was nice.  Ill probably only be able to drink this on special occasions due to the price.  Anywho... a great Scottish ale.  Strong. Malty.  Smooth.
Balanced strength. Not overpowering like the typical Scottish; this genre is hard to calibrate well, I suppose. This is a good example of it being done well. Explodes in the nose.
i love scotish ale,this one made me almost cream my pants with joy,best scot ale next to old jock.harsh at first but going down repays all the harshness.

One of the finest beers Ive ever tasted.  Strong butterscotch flavor/aroma - normally an off-flavor, its anything but in this brew.  Caramel and toffee with a hint of chocolate blend in a beer with suprisingly drinkable body - not heavy or cloying.  I obviously had a bottle that was in good condition.  I will seek this beer out again!
Soft mouth feel, bitter sweet finish,  a little sweet for me.  Welcome alcohol presence.  A nice beer.
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004  Oaky, rooty, dry, and some sweet chocolate to taste.  Great silky body that just slides down the throat like no other and not a bad looking head.  Tasty rendition.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Very pretty, dark brown to red, very light, but creamy looking head. Smells of red wine, with a slight buttery/alcohol (butterscotch) aroma. Tastes like a nice dry red wine with subtle carbonation. Medium body, light taste. I imagine this is what a carbonated red wine would taste like, different, but good.
Deep mahogany color with a quickly dissipating head.  Red wine nose. Very dry, with an almond, slightly amaretto flavor.  Overall, a bit bland and flat, but better than average.

I really like the color of this beer. Its a nice pretty almost red color. The smell seemed oaky... or something. It seemed like it was 50 years old or something. It tasted like it too. It tastes like a deep old beer. With an alcoholic aftertaste. Overall, I liked this beer as it has a drinkable quality, nice good flavor.
Huge amount of flavors. Oak and molasses and a nice fruitiness and smooth mouthfeel. A little overpriced but a nice ale.
Sickly sweet.  Yuk.  If there is one type of beer I hate, it is too sweet beer.  And Traquair is TOO SWEET.  The only reason I choked it down was because of its price.
Im not this beers biggest fan by a long shot, but its a good one nonetheless, certainly better than the atrocious Jacobite Ale.  This one is smooth, malty, toasty and very warming.
Beautiful color, with garnet highlights. Massive malt aroma and flavor. Worth every penny.

Ill go with the concensus here, it does in fact smell like SA Triple Bock, however this is only a moderate-dark brown color, and is carbonated.  Thinner bodied (compared to Triple Bock though!), very malty and sweet.  This may well be the most complex beer Ive ever tried...I cant even begin to pick out everything.  I definitely detect some vanilla in there, perhaps some maple, a hint of sherry.  Aftertaste only becomes more complex while remaining sweet, and the beer itself gets better with every sip.  Something you *must* experience - slowly - for yourself.  Personally, I enjoyed it very much.
Ill agree w/ beergirl, smells just like Sam Adams Triple Bock.  The body is thinner and the maple flavor a bit more pronounced.
Smells like Sam Adams Triple Bock, but tastes much better. VERY smooth.
A good Scottish ale - full of malty flavour.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2004 clear and bright dark reddish-brown colour, fine head, complex aroma of licorice, wood and alcohol, slightly roasted, sweet and full-bodied with a toasted bitter malty finish - this beer seems to have a huge ageing potentiel
